message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypoplastic tonsils and adenoids, recurrent infections, and decreased levels of CD19, CD20, and CD21 cells suggest a diagnosis of X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which is caused by mutation in the tyrosine kinase gene. Option A refers to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, option C refers to DiGeorge syndrome, and option D refers to chronic granulomatous disease, all of which have different sets of symptoms and genetic causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options, only mutation in a tyrosine kinase gene is associated with primary immunodeficiency disorders, specifically X-linked agammaglobulinemia. The other options are associated with different genetic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a decreased level of B cells (CD19, CD20, and CD21) which indicates a B-cell deficiency disorder. Among the options, only mutation in tyrosine kinase gene can cause X-linked agammaglobulinemia, a B-cell deficiency disorder. Mutations in other genes, such as WAS and NADPH oxidase, do not cause this disorder. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 can cause DiGeorge syndrome, which is an immune deficiency disorder, but it usually presents with hypoplastic thymus and parathyroid glands.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s decreased levels of cells expressing CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggest a B-cell deficiency, which is a characteristic of X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). XLA is caused by a mutation in the BTK (Bruton's tyrosine kinase) gene. Option A refers to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which is characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immune deficiency. Option C refers to DiGeorge syndrome, which is characterized by hypoparathyroidism, hypocalcemia, and congenital heart disease. Option D refers to chronic granulomatous disease, which is characterized by recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggest a B cell deficiency. The most likely cause is a mutation in the tyrosine kinase gene, which leads to X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Mutations in the WAS gene lead to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which presents with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. Microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22 is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with hypoplastic thymus and parathyroid glands, and cardiac abnormalities. Mutation in NADPH oxidase gene is associated with chronic granulomatous disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of recurrent infections, hypoplastic tonsils and adenoids, and decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggest a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options, a mutation in tyrosine kinase gene is most associated with decreased levels of B-cells and recurrent respiratory tract infections. WAS gene mutation is associated with eczema and thrombocytopenia. Microdeletion on chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome. Mutation in NADPH oxidase gene causes chronic granulomatous disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggest a diagnosis of X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). XLA is caused by a mutation in the tyrosine kinase gene. Mutation in the WAS gene results in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22 results in DiGeorge syndrome, and mutation in NADPH oxidase gene results in chronic granulomatous disease, none of which relate to the symptoms described in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has recurrent infections and a decreased number of cells expressing CD19, CD20, and CD21, which are markers for B cells. The most likely cause is a mutation in a tyrosine kinase gene, which plays a role in B cell development and function. Options A, C, and D are associated with other conditions and not consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21 suggest a defect in B-cell development or function. Among the options, only a mutation in tyrosine kinase gene can result in this type of immunodeficiency, specifically X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Other abnormalities are associated with different types of immunodeficiencies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s decreased levels of cells expressing CD19, CD20, and CD21 are suggestive of a B-cell deficiency. Among the options, only a mutation in the tyrosine kinase gene is associated with X-linked agammaglobulinemia which is a B-cell deficiency disorder. Patients with X-linked agammaglobulinemia have hypoplastic tonsils and adenoids, recurrent respiratory tract infections, and are susceptible to giardiasis and viral gastroenteritis.
